title: National Assembly of Sudan
text:
The National Assembly (, "Al-Maǧlis al-Waṭaniy") is the lower house of the <a href="National%20Legislature%20of%20Sudan">National Legislature</a> of <a href="Sudan">Sudan</a>. The Legislature was unicameral until 2005. The upper house is the <a href="Council%20of%20States%20of%20Sudan">Council of States</a> ("Majlis Welayat").
The National Assembly was dissolved on 11 April 2019 following a <a href="2019%20Sudanese%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">military coup</a> which overthrew Sudan President Omar al-Bashir and Assembly's ruling National Congress Party.
As part of the <a href="2019%20Sudanese%20transition%20to%20democracy">2019 Sudanese transition to democracy</a>, a <a href="Transitional%20Legislative%20Council%20%28Sudan%29">Transitional Legislative Council</a> is to be formed which will function as the legislature of Sudan until elections scheduled for 2022.
Speakers.
<a href="Hassan%20al-Turabi">Hassan Abdallah al-Turabi</a> was the speaker from 1996 until he stripped of the post in December 1999, and placed under arrest after a falling out with President <a href="Omar%20al-Bashir">Omar al-Bashir</a>.
2015-2019 session.
The most recent session was <a href="Sudanese%20general%20election%2C%202015">elected in 2015</a>.
2010-2015 session.
<a href="Sudan">Sudan</a> was previously in a transitional period following the signing of a <a href="Naivasha%20Agreement">Comprehensive Peace Agreement</a> (CPA) on 9 January 2005 that officially ended the <a href="Second%20Sudanese%20Civil%20War">civil war</a> between the Sudanese Government (based in <a href="Khartoum">Khartoum</a>) and the southern-based <a href="Sudan%20People%27s%20Liberation%20Movement">Sudan People's Liberation Movement</a> (SPLM) rebel group. The National Assembly consisted of 450 appointed members who represent the government, former rebels, and other opposition political parties. The National Assembly, whose members were appointed in mid-2005 replaced the latest elected parliament. All members of the National Legislature serve six-year terms. Article 117 of the Interim Constitution called for the 450 members of the National Assembly to be appointed according to the following power-sharing formula:
<a href="National%20Congress%20%28Sudan%29">National Congress</a> Party (52%)
Other Arab political parties (14%)
<a href="Sudan%20People%27s%20Liberation%20Movement">Sudan People's Liberation Movement</a> (28%)
Other Black political parties (6%)
Composition of the National Assembly following the 2010 election and the independence of <a href="South%20Sudan">South Sudan</a>.
Parliament building.
The seat of the National Assembly is <a href="Omdurman">Omdurman</a>, immediately north-west of the country's capital <a href="Khartoum">Khartoum</a>. The building was designed in the style of <a href="brutalist%20architecture">brutalist architecture</a> by the Romanian architect <a href="Cezar%20L%C4%83z%C4%83rescu">Cezar Lăzărescu</a> and completed in 1978. It is located on the banks of the <a href="White%20Nile">White Nile</a> at the confluence with the <a href="Blue%20Nile">Blue Nile</a> near the old Omdurman bridge.
